message:
I am offering free #accommodation to Grenfell Tower residents in Englefield Green, TW20 for three weeks from tomorrow. I will be abroad from 16th of June to 7th of July so I am offering my double room. It is suitable for single occupancy or a couple. Please forward this post to anyone who might need accommodation.
#GrenfellTower

I note also that the phrase used is "requisitioned", meaning that the owners would be at minimum compensated, or more likely, paid market rate rent. So your ill-educated crap about communism is utterly irrelevant.

Compulsory purchase orders are nothing new. Local authorities use them all the time. 

Funny how no-one moans about socialism when CPOs are used to make way for a new Tesco, or a golf course for Donald Trump.

Also, equating Communism with Fascism as if they were the same thing shows how little you know about Communism. Communism is an umbrella term for socialist states that distribute wealth according to need as opposed to an "every man for himself" race of capitalism. Marxist theory states that the workers should own the means of production, not the state. So there is nothing in Communist theory about single state dictatorships being needed. That's the realm of Leninist-Communism where the state owns the means of production and suppresses descent.

And even then, simply suggesting that people should share wealth to help those most in need isn't a default slippery slope to Communism. While one needs to be a socialist to be a fascist or a communist, one does not have to be a fascist or communist to be a socialist.

Hammersmith simply hasn't got the capacity to help much. When I had to move home 4 years ago, simply because my landlord didn't want to rent to someone claiming housing benefit, I came within a 4 days of being placed in B and B, but was eventually found emergency housing which was infested with bedbugs and mice, as well as having faulty electric plugs and damp. I am totally blind and have long term mental health problems, that is why I am currently unable to work, and it still took Hammersmith and Fulham 9 months to find me permanent accommodation. However that was under the conservative council, since Labour won control of the council in 2014 and since July 2015 the council hasn't placed any families in B and B. Where as before families with disabled children were placed in B and B, in one case for over three months. LBHF has made amazing improvements to how it uses its housing stock, but it simply doesn't have the resources to bail out a council like RBKC, who simply haven't bothered. Forgive the essay, but I suppose my point is that because of my own experience of terrible housing problems, one of the first things I did yesterday on hearing the news was to call RBKC and offer to take a couple of people in. An awful lot of the generosity that has poured out in response to this disaster has come from those with the least.

It is a horrifying tragedy, but it was not just an 'accident', and it is political, because there is a long history of neglect going up to it. You can't expect people to just ignore that!

They are not yet sure what caused the fire exactly, but they are pretty sure what made it worse, and what made it more difficult for firefighters,. It is things that the residents group have been going on about for years, but kept getting ignored by the privatised property management company, the Tory council and the Tory MP. They even warned that something like this could happen on their blog not long ago.

There is a causal link to Tory government cuts  this past 7 years, and Boris Johnsons cuts as London mayor. Their austerity, cuts to funding to local councils, cuts to fire services,  deregulation and inaction over the housing crisis did not help. 

Here's a timeline of what's happened leading up to this so you can see how it was political and why so many people are so angry as well as upset... No it's not directly Theresa May's fault, but her party's policies, actions and inaction the past 7 years have made things worse. 

People are highlighting this stuff, and demonstrating and spreading this info online to make sure those responsible are brought to justice and to make sure things change to prevent it ever happening again.

2009 - Lakanal House tower block catches fire killing 6 people. The local authority is prosecuted for lapses in fire safety. A review is promised by the Labour government after pressure from the Fire Protection Association (FPA).

2010 - Building Regulations Act is published, including provisions for fire safety. Conservatives win election, a review is promised by the new government after more pressure from the FPA and warnings that the BR act does not go far enough.

2013 - Boris Johnson overrules the ruling body of the London Fire Brigade and uses legal action to inflict £29m in cuts. Closing 10 fire stations, cutting firefighters by 552, losing 14 fire engines and cutting minimum staffing levels from 5 to 4. By the time he steps down as Mayor of London he inflicts a further £100m in cuts to £130m total and the loss of 7000 firefighters. Fire prevention measures carried out by the service drop by over 25%.

2013 - All Party Parliamentary Group on Fire Safety and Rescue produces a report strongly recommending installation of fire suppression systems and sprinklers in 4000 tower blocks throughout Britain. The Grenfell residents action group publishes a report warning that their landlord is putting their safety at risk by restricting the access ways to their car park. They are ignored by their landlord.

2013 - 2016 Conservative housing ministers sit on All Party report without action, promising they are "looking at it", including housing minister Gavin Barwell.
2016 - Conservatives vote against a Labour motion to make sure all landlords and housing associations ensure residences are fit for human occupation, including provisions for fire safety. The motion is denied by 312 votes to 219. 72 of the MP's voting against are landlords. The Grenfell residents action group publish a report warning people will die in a fire before the landlord takes notice of their poor fire safety provisions. They are ignored by their landlord.

2017 - Ex housing minister Gavin Barwell becomes Prime Minister Theresa May's chief of staff. He never actioned the report. Grenfell Tower is reduced to rubble with the deaths of at least 12 residents as a fire spreads through the building in 4 minutes. It has no fire suppression system or sprinklers. The stairwell is not adequate for a full building evacuation. The emergency lighting is missing from half of the floors. The fire service struggle to reach the building due to previous car park modifications causing access issues as warned by the resident action group in 2013.
